subject: Re: Junit Test Selections for testfunc()
msgSnippet: I tried doing this, but it executed only the last one.:myruntests [1]); 4 times:: Why is it so??? I would like to run all these tests at 7,3,1 in respective
messageBody:
I tried doing this, but it executed only the last one.:myruntests
[1]); 4 times::
Why is it so???
I would like to run all these tests at 7,3,1 in respective order.
All other One time Setup works, thank you.

public static Test suite() {
TestSuite suite = new TestSuite();
MyTest test = new MyTest();

String myruntests[]={"testGetDiseaseManager016",
"test1",
"test2",
"test3",
"test4",
"test5",
"test6",
"test7"};
test.setName(myruntests[7]); suite.addTest(test);
test.setName(myruntests[3]); suite.addTest(test);
test.setName(myruntests[1]); suite.addTest(test);
suite.addTest(test);
TestSetup wrapper = new TestSetup(suite) {

protected void setUp() {
oneTimeSetUp();
}

protected void tearDown() {
oneTimeTearDown();
}
};

return wrapper;

}




--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "J. B. Rainsberger" <jbrains@r...>
wrote:
> love wrote:
> >
> >
> > I have 10 Junit tests in my TestSuite starting test Functions like
> > ...extends TestCase{
> > testa1()
> > testb2().....
> >
> > ...
> > testj10()
> > }
> >
> >
> > and I can run each one separately with IntellijIdea Editor.
> > Say I can run only testa1() or testb2() or ...
> >
> > OR whole MyTest Class.
> >
> >
> > What can I do to have such a facility through java code using
JUnit.
> >
> > How can I select which test to run ? even though I have read all
> > tutorials and practically conducted most of the tests
successfully,
> > about this feature I am ignorant.
>
> Create a TestSuite of only one test. You can choose the test to
execute
> by setting the test's name:
>
> public class SingleTest {
> public static Test suite() {
> TestSuite suite = new TestSuite();
> MyTestCase test = new MyTestCase();
> test.setName("testHello");
> suite.add(test);
> }
> }
>
> Good luck.
> --
> J. B. (Joe) Rainsberger
> Diaspar Software Services
> http://www.diasparsoftware.com
> Author, JUnit Recipes: Practical Methods for Programmer Testing
